column6: In April 2020 a relief measure adopted by the Government and implemented by the universal supplier OSHEE allows certain categories of households and small business customers to enter into an agreement with the supplier based on which all accrued interest on non-paid electricity bills (not the principal amount) which has accumulated until 31 December 2019 will be written off.

On 5 April 2020, the Sonelgaz group and its distribution company SADEG decided not to interrupt the electricity and gas service in case of non-payment of bills due to the spread of the coronavirus on the national territory.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply

column6: On 26 May 2020, the government of Angola announced that electricity and water consumers could pay their bills in instalments until 27 July 2020, instead of single payments.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply

column6: On 27 March 2020, the Antigua Public Utilities Authority initially halted the disconnection of all utility services provided by the Authority for three months, until June 2020. This ban was extended several times, and currently lasts until at least the end of November 2020.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply
column6: On 27 March 2020, the Antigua Public Utilities Authority (APUA) announced it would apply a 10% automatic reduction on fuel variance for all domestic energy bills, along with a further 10% discount on energy consumption when the bill is fully paid in the due month. This means a total maximum discount of 20% can be attained. On 23 June 2020, these measures were extended with an upwards increase of the discount for timely payment to 15%. On 25 August 2020, this COVID-19 Utility Discount for domestic accounts was further extended to September and October 2020.

On 25 March 2020, the government prohibited companies from cutting the electricity, gas, water, phone and internet services due to default or non-payment of up to three consecutive or alternate invoices, from 1 March 2020, for a period of 180 days (6 months) (DNU 311/2020). The moratorium was extended several times, most recently until  31 March 2021. Users with notices of disconnection in progress are included too, and in no case companies can cite security reasons. The measure applies to specific vulnerable persons: including those who are beneficiaries of the Universal Child Allowance (AUH), Pregnancy Allowance, non-remunerative pensions, enrolled in the social monotax, retirees who earn the minimum credit, workers who earn minimum wage, beneficiaries of unemployment insurance, electro-dependents, persons employed at home and exempt from the ABL. When pre-payment users do not pay their consumption recharge, providers must similarly provide services in a normal and usual way. The measure also applies to registered Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises, registered cooperatives, and public and private health institutions.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply

column6: On 25 March 2020, the government approved a price freeze on liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) in carafes, cylinders and/or bulk destined for domestic market consumption for 180 days (meaning until mid-September 2020).

On 18 June 2020, the government extended a rate freeze for electricity that had been in place prior to the pandemic, as well as a rate freeze on natural gas supplies imposed in April 2020, until December 2020 due to the difficult economic situation of COVID-19.

On 25 March 2020, the Armenian Public Services Regulatory Commission (PSRC) recognized the situation in the country as force majeure and decided that supplier companies are not entitled to suspend the supply of electricity, gas and drinking water to their customers if they fail to fulfill their payment obligations, Consumers are not exempt from payment obligations however. Supposedly, on 22 April 2020, this position was reversed due the risk of 'systemic collapse' of the energy provision system, and suppliers were allowed to be stricter.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply
column6: On 13 April 2020, the Armenian government announced that a lump sum payment to the amount of 50% of natural gas and electricity consumed in February would be offered to those subscribers to gas and electricity supply contracts will bills lower than 10,000 drams for natural gas consumption, and 5,000 drams for electricity consumption in February, 2020. A further lump sum comparable to 30% of the bill is offered for those with gas consumption between 10,000 and 30,000 AMD, and electricity consumption between 5,000 and 10,000 AMD. There is no need to apply: the money is automatically transferred to the utility operator. It seems suggested this measure may be available for the bills of April, May and June.

On 27 March 2020, the Australian Energy Regulator published its Statement on "Reasonable expectations of energy companies to protect householders and small business customers during the COVID-19 pandemic". As part of the recommendations, companies are asked to offer all households and small businesses indicating they may be in financial stress a payment plan or hardship arrangement. Companies have committed to deferral of payments of bills up to 31 July 2020.

On 27 March 2020, the Australian Energy Regulator published a document called "Reasonable Expectations of Energy Companies to Protect Householders and Small Business Customers during the COVID-19 pandemic". The document expects companies to not disconnect customers who may be in financial stress, without their agreement before 31 July 2020 and potentially beyond. Energy companies have generally committed to not apply disconnections. These expectations were updated to apply until 30 June 2021, and beyond when consumers are subject to stay-at-home orders, with slight variation in requirements.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply

column6: On 27 March 2020, the Australian Energy Regulator published its Statement on "Reasonable expectations of energy companies to protect householders and small business customers during the COVID-19 pandemic". As part of the recommendations, companies are asked to defer referral to debt collection agencies, or credit default listing until at least 31 July 2020 and potentially beyond. Renewed statements, with slightly different instructions as the pandemic unfolded were released every four months. Currently, the statement protects those who are subject to stay-at-home orders mostly.
On 20 March 2020, the Austrian government announced that an agreement was signed with energy suppliers to ban disconnection during the lockdown until May 1.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply

column6: Deferred electricity payment to the next month offered by distribution systems operators (DSOs) to consumers, who declare facing financial difficulties due to the pandemic and payment in instalments allowed.
The heating supply operator stops sending disconnection notices due to payment arrears

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply

column6: On 5 April 2020, the government temporarily increased the preferential rates for basic levels of energy consumption from 300 kWhs to 400 kWhs for April and May 2020. This means that the price of one kWh up to 400 kWh is $0.04. If this limit is exceeded, for every kilowatt-hour above the limit, the tariff is $0.6.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply

column6: On 17 March 2020, Bahrain government announced a COVID-19 relief package that would see Electricity and Water Authority utility bills automatically paid for all Bahraini individuals and businesses for three months during April, May, June 2020 (up to the costs incurred during the same period in 2019). The measure was extended for Bahrani residents' first homes, and currently applies through October, November and December 2020.

On 22 March 2020, the government announced that household consumers will not be charged extra for delayed payment of gas and electricity bills until 30 June. An official circular issued by the Energy and Mineral Resources Division indicated that a large number of household consumers have to visit banks to pay gas bills which may increase the risks of coronavirus transmission. The government decided to defer the timeframe for the payment of household consumers bills as defined by Gas Distribution Regulations 2014, now allowing consumers to pay their bills of February-May at any convenient time in June 2020 without any extra charge. On 10 June 2020, the Minister for Power, Energy and Mineral Resources announced in a virtual press briefing that the policy will likely not be extended.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply

column6: On 26 March 2020, two Banghadeshi gas distribution companies increased the emergency balance for domestic prepaid meters during the nationwide shutdown, from Tk200 to Tk2,000 for customers of Titas Gas Transmission and Distribution Company Limited – supplying gas in Dhaka and Mymensingh. It increased the balance to Tk1,000 for customers of Karnaphuli Gas Distribution Company Ltd – the gas supplier in Chattogram. These are the only companies with pre-payment subscribers for gas. If the situation improves within a short time, the gas distributing companies will adjust the amount in the next few months, and payments will be arranged through the following months energy bills. A balance of Tk2,000 equates to an average of four months of gas consumption.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply

column6: In April 2020, the energy cooperative Energie 2030 announced it would offer special tariffs to all: night tariffs to all even during the day.
In April 2020, Lampiris announced it would offer the night tariff for all consumers for April's electricity bill.

On 27 March 2020, Belize Electricity Limited (BEL), the country's sole electricity provider, indicated it would suspend disconnections at least through April 2020, for all customers in the Social and Residential classifications countrywide, and for all hotel, restaurant and tour operator accounts.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply
column6: On 27 March 2020, Belize Electricity Limited (BEL), the country's main electricity provider announced via its media channels it provided  assistance to 7,000 customers (social rate) by cancelling their electricity bills for two months, during February-April 2020. Credits are applied to accounts, even if customers already paid these bills. (Social classification refers to customers who consume an average of 60 kWh or less monthly, solely for domestic use.)
On 1 April 2020, the Government (Art. 29, Supreme Decree 4206) allowed users and/or consumers to pay for their electricity services within the three months after the lifting of the quarantine.

On 1 April 2020, the Government prohibited electricity disconnections (as well as any late payment sanction) for non-payment of the bills of January, February and March 2020 (Art. 29, Supreme Decree 4206). Unpaid bills would be paid in the next three months after the end date of the strict lockdown period.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply
column6: On 1 April 2020, the Government (Art. 24 and 25, Supreme Decree 4206) established a  bill reduction scheme for potable water, gas and electricity for April, May and June 2020. Energy consumption is discounted with 100% for those will bills up to 120Bs

On 1 April 2020, the Government (Art. 24, Supreme Decree 4206) established a reduction of the 100% on the electric energy bills for three months for residential consumers with low consumption up to Bs 120 (April, May, June). The Government also established a 50% reduction of the potable water and gas for all households during these months.
The power utility of Bosnia and Herzegovina (EP BiH) adopted a decision not to disconnect customers in case of non-payment during the crisis (whereas no such measure was adopted by the government).

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply
column6: The Government recommended the power utility of Republika Srpska (ERS) to waive interest rates from unpaid electricity bills for March, April and May 2020.

On 24 March 2020, Aneel (Energy National Agency) banned electricity disconnections for non-payments during 90 days for domestic consumers. The measure was extended from 23 June 2020 until 31 July 2020.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply

column6: On 8 April 2020, the Government exempted consumers who benefit from the social tariff from payment for consumption of up to 220 kWh / month, for three months in April, May and June. The measure supposedly benefits more than 9 million low-income families, and involved an investment of R $ 900 million

On 23 June 2020, regulator ANEEL announced its Conta-COVID strategy whereby tariff increases affecting consumers bills would be spread out over five years (through bank loans for utilities up till up to R $ 16.1 billion), rather than 12 months. This preserves affordability of energy bills in the short and medium term, while allowing utilities to cover their costs. According to ANEEL, it was necessary to create a loan operation to serve the sector because the collection of energy distributors was greatly affected by the pandemic, at an estimated loss of 6.3% in the average collection of the distribution sector in the period.
On 30 March 2020, the period within which consumers can pay their electricity bills is doubled from 10 to 20 days after the invoices are released.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply
column6: On 22 July 2020, the government announced it would provide nearly BGN 500 of targeted heating assistance to those in need for the coming winter season, increasing the amount by BGN 30 compared to last year. The measure applies from 1 November 2020 to 31 March 2021.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply
column6: On 2 April 2020, the government announced that households using single-phase 5-10 amp meters will benefit from a 50 percent reduction in consumption over the next three months. This corresponds to a consumption of 50 kWh. Also, village electricity cooperatives (COPEL) will benefit from the same conditions. All of these households will also benefit from the cancellation of fees, all taxes related to electricity and late payment penalties. Free consumption is availlable to those using single-phase 3 amp meters up to 75 KW / H over the period going from April to June, whether they subscribe to the post paid or prepaid system.

On 2 April 2020, the government announced that households using single-phase 3 amp meters will benefit from free consumption of up to 75 kWh over the period from April to June, whether they subscribe to the post paid or prepaid system, better known as Cash power. Similarly, households using single-phase 5-10 amp meters will benefit from a 50% reduction in consumption over the next three months. This corresponds to a consumption of 50 kWh. Also, village electricity cooperatives (COPEL) will benefit from the same conditions. All of these households will also benefit from the cancellation of fees, all taxes related to electricity and late payment penalties.

On 2 April 2020, the President of Burkina Faso announced that for the months of April, May and June there would be a 50% discounts on solar kits in the context of the Solar Home System project for vulnerable households.

In May 2021, state-run Electricité du Cambodge (EdC) announced it was not planning to cut off  electricity in the red, orange and yellow zones during the lockdown period,  especially to "brothers and sisters who run small businesses or workers and migrant workers or students staying in rented units" so as to deal with hardship from the COVID-19 outbreak

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply
column6: In April 2021, the Prime Minister announced during a televised speech that several types of households were eligible for payment of water and electricity bills in relation to COVID-19 outbreaks and lockdowns. Specifically, the government announced it would plan to cover utility bills for families who had a member die of COVID-19 for five months. For those with a family member testing positive, the State pays for three months, from the date the infection is confirmed. Families in lockdown or quarantain would receive two month water and electricity payments. Higher income families were urged to reject government support so it may benefit poorer families. It is unclear whether this policy has been actively implemented.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply

column6: In early April 2020, Eneo (the energy supplier) recommended that its customers consult their electricity bills from their mobile phone and pay them by mobile payment. This is made possible via the services Orange Money, MTN Mobile Money, Express Union Mobile and UBA, all partners of the company. For the first two services, the most widely used, payment charges were suspended: zero charges on bill payments of up to 25,000 FCFA for MTN Mobile Money, and full suspension of charges until 30 June for Orange Money.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply

column6: On 15 April 2020, the President of Chad announced that the Government pays the invoices of April, May and June 2020 of the National Electricity Company for domestic electricity users in the social bracket. This includes prepayment users.

On 7th April 2020, the Ministry of Energy announced that qualifying households who accumulated debts during the COVID-19 period would be able to spread out payment of these debts over a period of up to 12 months after the crisis ends, without any fines or interest. This plan will be available to more than 3,000,000 Chilean families (approximately 7 million people) who make up 40% of lower income households. In addition, households with proven vulnerability or inability to pay their bills due to the crisis may also be able to access this benefit, including: people aged over 60 years old with payment difficulties, and people who have lost their jobs.

On 7th April 2020, the Ministry of Energy announced that for as long as the pandemic lasts, electricity service may not be cut to due to debts, including for households who had accumulated debts of up to 10 UF (~ 360 USD) before the crisis.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply

column6: On 19th June 2020, the Superintendency of Electricity and Fuels (SEC), confirmed it  instructed liquefied gas companies to require a series of safety measures at the time of sale and delivery of liquefied gas cylinders, popularly known as “gas balloons”, in order to avoid the spread of Covid-19. These safety measures include workers maintaining a distance of at least 1 meter, temperature controls at the entrance to buildings, sanitizing cylinders and delivery trucks, and the use of personal protection equipment. Cylinders are the most used gas container in the country, with 59 million units of this type of container sold last year, with a greater use during winter for water heaters and stoves.

On 7th April 2020, the Ministry of Energy announced that it would not apply the winter surcharge during April and May, to provide economic relief for households, SMEs, and industry. The winter surcharge takes the form of a ‘peak hours’ charge from 18:00 to 22:00 and is usually applied between April to September, corresponding with when the electricity system faces its highest levels of consumption.

On 14 April 2020, the Government announced that Colombians in residential consumption strata 1 and 2 will automatically have payment of energy and water bills deferred, up to 36 months for repayment. This affects approx. 60% of subscribers. Those in residential consumption strata 3 and 4 have been offered 24 month repayment periods. This applies to bills from April and May, and to the amounts of energy that were not already subsidized in these strata under existing subsidies. Those who manage to repay in a timely manner receive 10% discount. In the case of consumers from strata 5 and 6, suppliers have to offer payment deferrals plans for the consumers that might require them.

On 14 April 2020, the Government announced that utilities no longer would be obliged to suspend energy provision after missing three payments, as provided for in Law 142 of 1994. On 22 April 2020, Enel Codensa announced that residential customers in strata 1, 2 ,3 and 4 will not be disconnected in Bogotá and Cundinamarca during the preventive isolation period. In case of customers from the 5th and 6th strata, the utility will offer personalised payment arrangements, but in case of non-payment the utility may disconnect.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply
column6: During the 2020 term, the Ministry of Mines and Energy may, as long as there is cash and budget availability for subsidy funds: i) assign subsidies in advance to companies that sell electricity and fuel gas with respect to their users 1, 2 And taking into account projections based on amounts of historical subsidies assigned to users served in their respective marketing market; (ii) granting new subsidies for strata 1 and 2 users of the residential public service of Liquefied Petroleum Gas, prior targeting according to the results obtained by the SISBEN in relation to the fuel used for cooking, in the same percentage applicable to the currently subsidized users and; iii) assign the subsidies for lower rates corresponding to the year 2019 to the trading companies, without the need to have a firm validation of the amounts.
Users from strata 4, 5, and 6 may make a voluntary contribution aimed at granting economic relief to the payment of home public services of electricity and fuel gas
By the end of April 2020, energy companies report that at least 8.400 reconnections of households in consumption strata 1, 2 and 3 have been carried out.

On 15 April 2020, the Ministry of Mines and Energy decided that the tarifs for energy and natural gas could not be increased, intially for two months, but later, it was decided to announce a tariff freeze until the end of 2020. In practice, many Colombian's have complained about their increase in bills, in part due to spending more time at home. The tariff freeze per kWh also does not affect any other increases of associated costs.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply

column6: On 1 April 2020, the Government has announced that the National Electricity Company (SNEL) and water supply company Regie de Distribution d'Eau (REGIDESO) will provide free water and electricity for all households for two months.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply
column6: On 19 March 2020, State-owned power company Te Aponga Uira (providing 90% of the Islands electricity demand) announced it will be providing free electricity and discounts to consumers in the Cook Islands due to the challenges posed by the pandemic. The company's package of assistance sees a reduction of electricity costs by 60 percent for businesses on the island of Rarotonga, effective from the first metre reading from 20 March until June. The policy is also extended to the Island of Aitutaki. The policies replace any existing discount facilities. The relief is offered on the premise of existing consumption levels of consumers, to be included in the monthly review.

On 19 March 2020, State-owned power company Te Aponga Uira (providing 90% of the Islands electricity demand) announced it will be providing free electricity to domestic electricity consumers in the Cook Islands due to the challenges posed by the pandemic. The company's package of assistance sees a 100% reduction of electricity tariffs, fees and charges effective from the first metre reading from 20 March 2020 until June 2020. After June 2020, the free energy programme was extended with a discount programme, amounting to up to $100 discount per month for households, for June, July and August 2020.

From 3 April 2020, the National Public Service Regulator has been recommending companies not to suspend electricity supply for households during the crisis. This is voluntarily implemented by some companies (ICE and CFNL), but not by others (ESPH). ICE and CFNL reportedly also covered up to 50% of energy bills of commercial and industrial entities, whereas Coopelesca R.L. applies the same service to domestic consumers. While a Government decreed moratorium on water suspension is in place, for electricity this is not (yet) the case. The Regulator provided such recommendations to the government.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply

column6: On 1 April 2020, authorities announced that payment deadlines for electricity bills would be extended with three months on the bills for April and May 2020, meaning until July and August 2020, for all households. The measure affects more than a million households, or more than six million Ivorians. This measure means that no penalty will be applied to customers, and that there will be no suspension of the supply of electricity due to non-payment from April 1. In addition, the settlement of these invoices can be made in several payments over the deferral period.
On 1 April 2020, the government decided that there would be no disconnection of electricity supplies until August 2020, due to unpaid bills during the pandemic.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply
column6: On 1 April 2020, the government decided to pay the electricity bills of more than one million vulnerable households paying the social electricity tariff (40% of consumers). This concerns bills to be paid in April and May 2020. For households on the social electricity tariff who have already paid their bills received in March, a credit note equivalent to the amount of the said bill will be granted to them on their next bills. For consumers with a prepayment meter, a free energy credit will be granted to them.

On 1 April 2020, the government decided to pay the electricity bills of more than one million vulnerable households (40% of consumers) paying the social electricity tariff. This concerns bills to be paid in April and May 2020. For households with the social electricity tariff who have already paid their bills received in March, a credit note equivalent to the amount of the said bill will be granted to them on their next bills. For consumers with prepayment meter, a free energy credit will be granted to them.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply

column6: In March the utility GEN-I cut prices by 15% for household customers under the standard pricelist. The measure applies until end of June.

On 8th April 2020, the national Government of Cuba announced a temporary pause in the collection of electricity, gas and water bills, but households are responsible for paying their bills once the utility offices reopen.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply

column6: On 20th April 2020, the Government issued advice during late April and early May for households to reduce their electricity consumption, with tips concerning cooking, use of air conditioning etc. This was linked to energy security.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply

column6: In March 2020, following a decision by Cyprus Electricity Regulatory Authority (CERA) and in accordance with a government proposal, the Electricity Authority Cyprus (EAC), the sole electricity provider in the country, announced a 10% discount on the price of electricity for two months, It was extended with another two months until June-July 2020. The extension represented approximately 20 million euro. However, bills have to be paid although financial hardships may be assessed on a case by case basis. In March 2020, following an EAC study and subsequent proposal, CERA also approved, by Decision 98/2020, a reduction to the Public Service Obligations (PSO) fee from â‚¬0,00071/kWh to â‚¬0,00055/kWh from 1 April 2020. The PSO fee is applied in accordance with the relevant legislation that empowers the Minister of Energy to ask CERA to impose on suppliers of electricity a lower charge per unit to specific categories of vulnerable consumers.
On 16 March 2020, consumers were allowed by utilities to postone energy payment up to 3 months.
Companies have stopped disconnecting consumers who can't pay their bill because of the pandemic

column6: Companies can offer interest free repayment schedule to their consumers

On 3 June 2020, the government announced that electricity bills for June of all consumers would be transferred to July, and that consumers would be given an additional three months to pay these bills. Payments can be made in installments, and there will be no disconnections during this period.

On 3 June 2020, the Government of Djibouti announced several  measures to assist electricity consumers. One of these is a delayed payment scheme for energy bills incurred in June, over three months in July, August and September 2020. During this period,  disconnection of energy will not occur.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply
column6: On 3 June 2020, the government announced that about 94% of all domestic energy consumers would receive assistance with paying electricity bills incurred during the confinement period. For about 54,046 subscribers (supposedly covering around 400,000 Djiboutians) with a contract for subscribed power of 1 kVA and 3-6 kVAactive during the confinement period, an amount of 30,000 DJF will be credited to the next billing.

On 27 March 2020, the Dominican regulator prohibited all energy distribution companies, both public and private, from cutting power to users for lack of payments during the 25 days covered by the COVID-19 emergency period decreed by the Government

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply

column6: On 17 April 2020, the Ecuadorian Electricity Regulation and Control Agency decided that the collection of bills corresponding to consumption of March and April 2020 would be deferred for dignity rate clients, small businesses, and artisanal industrialists. From June 2020, they can be paid in installments over a period of 12 months, without application of surcharges or interest.
On 17 April 2020, the government ordered there would be no suspension of electricity supply due to non-payment for bills issued in April and May 2020 (applies to consumers of residential rates

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply
column6: On 17 April 2020, the Government announced that during the emergency period (April and May 2020) those receiving dignity rates for electricity consumption (a rate of four cents per kilowatt hour, compared to 9.5 cents in the rest of the country) will benefit from this rate even if their consumption exceeds the energy consumption cap due to quarantine measures. The regular cap for dignity rates is less than 110 kilowatt hours per month in the Sierra and less than 130 kWh per month in the Costa, Amazonia and the Galapagos. This group supposedly comprises 1.5-2 million persons, or 30% of all residential consumers. On 30 July 2020, the Government  announced it will further assume all excess consumption of residential users who used <500 kWh per month during the months March-August 2020. Their bills will be based on consumption of last year.

On 18 June 2020, the government lowered or freezed electricity tariffs for a range of low-volume consumer groups for the period of the state of health emergency (March- August 2020) in response to complaints about higher energy bills.

On 20 March 2020, the Government postponed payment of electricity, water, internet and phone bills of March, April and May up to 24 months (two years). Delays in payment do not affect consumers credit status.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply

column6: On 31 March 2020, the government of Equatorial Guinea announced a Health State of Alarm and in Decree 4272020 ordered that company SEGESA cannot cut off power to its customers during the period the Order is in force, as no citizen may go to pay their electricity bill. The Health Emergency and related measures were extended on 14 April 2020.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply
Discounts or subsidies for energy supply

column6: On 31 May 2020, the Estonian government launched the "COVID-19 extraordinary appartment building construction grant" to encourage reconstruction works on apartment buildings built before 2000. The grant aims to improve energy- efficiency of buidlings, indoor climate and safety, and to mitigate the effects of the COVID-19 emergency situation announced in March 2020 on the construction sector. The grant rate varies from 30-50% of discounts on construction costs, with a maximum amount of EUR 1 million per applicant

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply

column6: On 30 March 2020, the Eswatini Electricity Company (EEC) took an executive decision to defer the 2020/2021 tariff increase which was to be effected from the 1st April 2020 for a period of two months. This means the 2020/2021 tariff increase will now be effected as of the 1st June, 2020. This is in light of the State of Emergency declared in Eswatini on the 17th of March, 2020 following the COVID-19 coronavirus outbreak and the partial lockdown.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply

column6: On 26 March 2020, Energy Fiji Limited fully matches the state's existing 50 percent subsidy on the first 100 units of electricity for households earning less than $30,000 annually. This means up to the first 100 units are free for these consumers. The scheme applies to both post-paid and pre-paid consumers and was extended until 30 December 2020. By 4 June 2020, it was reported the scheme covers 35,106 families.
In November 2020, all EDF customers received a message informing them that the clients facing payment difficulties due to the COVID-19 crisis will benefit from more flexible payment schedules.

On 25 March 2020 a decree was adopted by the government to extend the disconnection ban, traditionally applied from November to end of March, until 31 May 2020. Energy suppliers are required not to disconnect households with bill arrears. On April 16 2020, EDF decided to extend the disconnection ban until 1 September 2020, and the Government ultimately decided to extent bans until 31 May 2021.

In November 2020 all EDF customers received the information from EDF that the utility was not going to disconnect nor reduce power nor impose late payment penalties for non-payment until January 15, 2021

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply
column6: On 15 April 2020, utility ENGIE announced that their clients benefiting from income support for energy (Cheque Energie) could have their fixed charges reimbursed for 2 months. On 16 April 2020, the PlÃ¼m energy supplier decided to offer 50% discount on the monthly fixed charges to all its clients during the time of the crisis.

On 16 April 2020, utility Ã‰lectricitÃ© de France (EDF) decided to introduce payment instalments on a case by case basis for households. On 31 March 2020, EDF had already announced that for SMEs bills and payment will be postponed until the end of the crisis and payment arrangements organised on a case by case basis. Following the lockdown utility ENGIE announced that SMEs could postpone the payment of their energy bills until the end of the crisis and smoothing over 6 months of deferred bills as from the end of the health crisis.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply

column6: On 26 April 2020, the Gabonese Energy and Water Company (SEEG) - on orders of the President - announced that it will provide free water and electricity to social rate consumers with a conventional low-voltage electricity meter and subscriptions for low levels of consumption (1-6kW).The consumers will be credited with 15,000-20,000 FCFA. The measure is expected to benefit 248,000 subscribers, at a monthly cost estimated at 4.958 billion CFA francs (7.55 million euros). It seems to have applied in two phases in May and June 2020.
There is no decision or regulation on disconnection ban by the government but no customer was disconnected due to delayed payment in March.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply

column6: On 1 April 2020, the government of Georgia announced it will fully cover utility bills for those consuming less than 200 kW of electricity and less than 200 cubic metres of gas. The relief will concern utility charges in March, April and May. According to the Minister of Economy Maia Tskitishvili, 1.2 million families will benefit from the coverage of electricity bills and 671 from the coverage of gas bills. The Energy Regulator has implemented a special platform for those citizens who wish to refuse the privileges for the purposes of solidarity. Deadline for refusing the benefits is 11th day of each month (during 3 month period).

On 23 March 2020, the goverment allowed household consumers and small business experiencing economic difficulties due to COVID-19 to suspend energy bill payment until 30 June 2020. If consumers cannot pay their gas or electricity bills, suppliers may not take legal action through debt collection companies, claim interest on arrears, or terminate the contract due to default.
On 20 March 2020, German Municipal energy providers anounced an agreement to not cut off defaulting costumers' due to the coronavirus crisis.

column5: Discounts or subsidies for energy supply

The Guyana Revenue Authority (GRA) today announced a range of additional tax relief measures that will assist Guyanese as the country grapples with the fight against the COVID-19 pandemic.

The tax relief, the entity stated, will support businesses and individuals who have been socially and economically disadvantaged by the threat of the virus.

Among the relief measures are:

Removal of VAT on Water and Electricity with effect from April 01, 2020, to June 30, 2020.
Removal of VAT on Domestic Air Travel with effect from April 08, 2020, to June 30, 2020.
Extension of the April 30 deadline for the filing of tax returns to June 30, 2020. However, estimated remaining taxes using “management financial statements”, for the Year of Income 2019 (Year of Assessment 2020) must be paid by April 30th, 2020.
Expediting the processing of VAT refunds for businesses and PAYE refunds for employees.

The waiver of VAT and duties on COVID 19 medical supplies and lab testing kits.
The granting of tax deductions for all donations made by local businesses to staff and health institutions for the treatment of the virus.
The deferral of the payment of advance corporate and individual advance taxes for the Year of Assessment 2021 (Year of Income 2020) and PAYE for affected businesses until June 30, 2020. Beneficiaries of the voucher include all residential customers who had an average electricity consumption of 123 kWh per month prior to the pandemic, over the months between March 2019-February 2020, and no more than 150 kWh per month during the months of January and February 2020. The subsidy is also available for residental users of electricity supplied by rural unconventional electricity systems registered as of March 2020. Nearly 5 million users are expected to be eligible.

On 25 April 2020, the Department of Energy (DOE) announced that payments of household electricity bills will occur on staggered basis, following the extension of the quarantine period. Customers are given a grace period for bills due from March 15 until May 15, and can pay in four installments. (This policy was later followed up by MERALCO and the regulator with a disconnection moratoria from August-December 2020. See disconnection ban.)

In July 2020, Meralco first announced a disconnection ban in response to electricity bill "shocks" reported by consumers. This ban was extended three times by either Meralco or the Energy Regulatory Commission (ERC), until at least March 2021. It applies to consumers with bills < 200kWh. . https://residential.meralco.com.ph/erc-advisory-faqs-residential-customers. In August 2021, Meralco announced that it would not apply disconnections to areas subjected to quarantine requirements. https://www.rappler.com/business/meralco-says-no-disconnection-areas-under-ecq-mecq-august-2021 |  https://company.meralco.com.ph/faqs-during-covid-19-times

column6: On 15 April 2020, the Inter-Agency Task Force for the Management of Emerging Infectious Diseases, announced free electricity in March and April for life-line consumers of electricity cooperatives with consumption < 50 kWh. This applies to an estimated 3 million consumers across the country, whose primary sources of income and livelihood were disrupted by the COVID-19 crisis.

On 12 March 2020, the Phillipines government froze the prices of firewood and charcoal for 60 days, and the prices of kerosene and household LPG (11-kilogram tanks and below) for 15 days, due to the COVID-19 State of Emergency,
In March 2020, an agreement was reached between the government and utilities to allow for a payment moratorium, but the ultimate decision is up to the company.
According to the Act of 31 March 2020 (O.J.2020.374), utilities cannot disconnect consumers during the pandemic.

On 8 April 2020, this measure was extended until 30 June and it was announced that consumers can pay electricity and gas bills in 12 monthly installments.

On 18 March 2020, the Regulatory Entity for Energy Services (ERSE) announced an extension of disconnection notices for electricity, natural gas and piped LPG of 30 days, in addition to the regular 20 day disconnection notice. The disconnection moratorium for  was twice extended, until 30 September 2020. This applied to situations of unemployment, COVID-19 infection, or loss of over 20% of household income. Consumers can ask their supplier for a payment plan of up to 12 monthly installments, without interest. Payments start on 30 November 2020. On 23 March 2020, and 8 April 2020 respectively, the Portugese Government also announced a disconnection moratorium for utility services during the duration of the State of Emergency.

column6: EDP offers a 20% discount on the electricity bill for two months to health-care professionals, COVID-19 Emergency services professionals and medical or emergency facilities.

On 9 April 2020, the Government allowed 220 projects of small and micro electricity producers (less than 1 MW), who were waiting for a licence, to begin producing immediately. This will be in place during the emergency state and after that producers will have 6 months to pay the usual licensing taxes.

On 20 April 2020, the Entidade Reguladora dos ServiÃ§os EnergÃ©ticos (ERSE) established a freeze on bottled gas prices during the emergency period until May 2020. On 1 April 2020, ERSE (Regulatory Entity for Energy Services) reduced the energy tariff for households in the regulated market by 3% from 7 April 2020 (5 euros per MWh). While citing concerns about COVID-19, the  reduction was informed by a decrease of electricity prices in wholesale markets.

On 16 March 2020, Senate Bill 1539 was adopted which prohibits the disconnection of water, electricity and telecommunications services without the consent of the client until 30 days after the emergency situation. The public or private entity failing to comply with the statute would be subject to a fine of up to $ 100,000.

Gazprom Neft is offering free deferred payment to small businesses, agricultural enterprises, taxi fleets and numerous other corporate clients", in the short term.

On 2 April 2020, the Russian goverment introduced a moratorium on fines for utility debts for gas, electricity, heating and water until 1 January 2021 for owners and users of premises in apartment buildings and residential buildings. and a moratorium on the verification of meters. After the lifting of these measures for the first three months, until 1 April 2021, service charges will be calculated based on the average meter indicators for the last six months.

After the 1 January 2021, with the lifiting of moratoriums on charging of late payment fines, notifications for payment (and disconnection) can be being sent to debtors whose debt is double the  normal electricity consumption, informing them that unless all unpaid bills are settled in full within 30 days, the debtors can be disconnected until repayment.

column6: Since 2 April 2020, the Government has been extending (simplified) provision of subsidies for housing and 'communal services' (utitliies) by not requiring new applications for extensions. Normally, the subsidies would be awarded for six months, and in order to extend subsidies, citizens had to re-apply and provide all the necessary documents in order to prove their need. This requirement has been lifted for everyone whose subsidy expired before April 1 st , 2021. From January 1, 2021, citizens will no longer have to provide receipts and checks for payment of housing and communal services, as well as certificates of absence of debt. Citizens who have more than a certain share of income each month have the right to receive subsidies. Each region sets this standard independently. For example, in Moscow you can get a subsidy if utility costs exceed 10% of the total family income, in St. Petersburg - 14%. Government agencies will themselves receive this information through the system of interdepartmental electronic interaction.

On 30 March 2020, the state-owned St. Kitts Electricity Company (SKELEC) announced in keeping with the government's COVID-19 Economic stimulus package that  eligible customers could apply for the three-month moratorium on payment of electricity bills, allowing for a three-month deferral period on electricity bills incurred in April, May, June 2020. The bill of March must be paid on or before July 2020. To be eligible, customers must prove financial impacts of COVID-19 through a letter from their employer, or submit evidence on self-employment within the tourism sector or any other sector affected by COVID-19.

On 14 October 2020 LUCELEC and the Government signed a Memorandum of Understanding entitling the most vulnerable consumers to receive credits worth the average monthly consumption of a low-income household, during October 2020 to March 2021 (six months). The  credits would be applied by LUCELEC and paid for by the Government of Saint Lucia. It estimated that approx. 5,000 to 6,000 of the most vulnerable households will benefit. St. Lucia has approximatly 180,000 inhabitants.

On 25 March 2020, the Government announced a COVID-19 response package which includes the provision that any unpaid bills incurred during the period of the disconnection moratorium would be subject to a deferred payment arrangments allowing incremental payment over a period of 24 months (two years).

On 25 March 2020, the Government announced a COVID-19 response package which includes a disconnection moratoria on the Vincent Electricity Company (VINLEC) and the Central Water and Sewerage Authority (CWSA) during three months, for any customer who is not in arrears for more than two months.

column6: On 17 April 2020, St Vincent Electricity Services Limited (VINLEC) announced a 15% discount on basic energy for three months, for all electricity accounts, during April, May and June 2020. In addition, no VAT will be applied to electricity accounts for domestic customers (and hotels and guest houses) for the same months. Those customers who self-generate renewable energy will also see a corresponding reduction of 15% in the amounts paid by VINLEC for the energy that is purchased by the company.

On 25 March 2020, the Government announced a COVID-19 response package which includes the announced that public utility companies Vincent Electricity Company (VINLEC) and the Central Water and Sewerage Authority (CWSA) agreed that customers do not have pay reconnection fees during the coming three months.

It reserves 15.5 billion Francs CFA for electricity and 3 billion Francs CFA for water bills. According to the Minister of Petroleum and Energies, subscribers who have already paid their bills, "will have a credit in the accounting of SENELEC". For SENELEC customers with the "Woyofal" subscription who have already purchased pre-payment credit, the amount will be repositioned. While procedures for pre-payment and post-payment will be different, the Government stresses that the financial effects will be the same.
Electric Power Industry of Serbia (EPS) will not charge penalties to customers in case of delayed electricity bill payment.

column6: On 19 February 2020, Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced that the annual goods and services tax (GST) voucher for utilities, U-Save, will be doubled for all eligible Housing Board households, so as to help with their utilities expenses during COVID-19, and to free up cash for other household costs. The U-Save scheme provides lower- and middle-income HDB households with quarterly rebates to offset their utilities bills and are paid in January, April, July and October each year. In respone to COVID-19 the rebates were increased several times, including with an additional U-Save voucher for families with more than five members. U-Save top-ups currently at least affect the U-Save payments up until October 2020 and January 2021. In addition, throughout 2020, several one-off cash payouts for all or specific Singaporeans households or persons aged 21 and up were also made, for some up to S$600.

The credit is given to households living in all types of property and will be credited in either the July or August utilities bill. This is addition to the measures announced in February 2020. See Singapore (I). On 5 June 2020, the Minister clarified that further support may be applied for by those in need, and awarded on a case-by-case bases, in case people marginally miss eligibility criteria and face hardship.
SPP, Slovakian utility, allowed households to postpone their advance payments for electricity and gas supply by 3 months

column6: In March 2020, the government and regulator undertook several measures to reduce the household electricity bill between 1 March 2020 and 31 May 2020. The regulator reduced some tariff items to zero costs, and cut the network charge by 33% for households and small firms. The government decided to suspend households and small businesses' payments of contributions for subsidies for high-efficiency co-generation and renewables. The measures together are estimated to reduce electricity bills up to 27%. An average household bill is normally 50 euros.
In March 2020, GEN-I was the first electricity supplier in Slovenia to cut the electricity prices paid by its household and small business customers by 15% from March 1 to May 31 2020.

column6: From 1 May 2020, Solomon Power will reduce electricity tariffs by 16%  in addition to the 44 cents reduction already being implemented which is expected to ease the immediate burden on households and businesses during the COVID-19 period.

On 31 March 2020, the Spanish goverment decided that under the State of Emergency,  disconnections of water and energy (gas and electricity) are forbidden to all households' 'first homes'. Per 1 October 2020, the government affirmed that electricity supply cuts the beneficiaries of the social bonus continues to be prohibited in certain cases, such as the case of minors, dependents or people with disabilities in the home. Specifically, electricity supply may not be suspended to essential customers in the following circumstances: a) severely vulnerable consumer at risk of social exclusion, b) beneficiary of the social bonus, proven to be part of a family unit in which there is at least one child under 16 years of age c) beneficiary of the social bonus, and any family unit member in a situation of recognized dependency of grade II or III, d) beneficiary of the social bonus, and family unit member with recognized disability equal to or greater than 33%. On 4 May, the ban was extended until 9 August 2021.

column6: On 17 March 2020, the Spanish Government announced an extension of the electricity social tariff for all households that have become vulnerable because of a decrease in income or the loss of employment during the coronavirus crisis. Households who are currently entitled to the social bonus can benefit from a discount of 25% or 40% on energy bills, depending on their degree of vulnerability, to facilitate the payment of bills incurred. The benefits were extended until 21 June 2021, and once more until 9 August 2021, for a new social bonus catgory of persons "in a situation of economic vulnerability due to COVID-19".
On 17 March 2020, the Spanish Government deciced to automatically extend the social tariff for electricity for households that were supposed to be renovated during the emergency period.

Energy company Iberdrola Spain offers free emergency services to elderly over 65 years. The company also offers payment flexibility by splitting bills into instalments, up to 12 months, at no cost, both in the open and regulated markets.
On 17 March 2020, the Spanish Government approved a moratorium on payments on basic supplies for self-employed workers and smalll and medium businesses.
On March 17th, the Spanish Government approved an Emergency regulation establishing a freeze on natural gas and bottled butane gas prices.

On 22 March 2020, the President announced as part of the "COVID-19 Health Care and Social Security Fund" that payment of electricity and water bills below 15,000 rupees can be extended till the 30th of April.

Up to 10 million households are expected to benefit. According to the relief proposal for households, free electricity shall be extended to households whose consumption does not exceed 150 units (kilowatts/hour) (up from 90 units previously, and 50 units before that). Electricity fees would be waived for households using less than 50 units, while consumption over 50 units is covered by the state welfare card up to Bt230 of the bill per household. The Ministry similarly announced waivers of payment of water bills, social security contributions (by both workers and employees), and rent on state properties.

The total estimated cost of these measures reaches close to $9 million over three months.
Soleva and BBOX (local suppliers) offered 1-month free electricity credits to their off-grid solar customers.
